reviewText:
I played and loved the Shadowrun Returns series but not enjoying Shadowrun Chronicles as much as SR.
This game completely pales in comparision to Shadowrun Returns series.  This game company has my money as a donation.

The only redeeming quality this game has is the multiplayer co-op quest playing, which Shadowrun Returns series does NOT have.  The thing is the multiplayer is laggy, buggy and has potential to crash or will quit if the game developer folds.

It is more challenging playwise soloing than SR, since you Don't have in-quest healing, do have lower hitpoints, limited armor and limited gear slots.  The shaman class is limited, so i have read.  Limited magic spells compared to SR.   Deckers do have more to do in combat, but not sure if there is in matrix runs.

Character creation is weird, you are given a sort of hybrid avatar, then you have to spend your earned karma points on what skills you want to make the avatar into a class.  Does have early job skill buffs choices.  Does have more alternate path skills to learn like lockpicking, demolishing, organ harvesting, but those do take points away from combat skills.  Has an Either / Or tiered system of picking skills.

Does have some better looking maps, npc and avatar than SR and has conversation voiceovers for avatars and npcs, with a Boston accent.

It is still in developement, maybe it will get better later.  Read more reviews, forum and wikis, then watch playthroughs on video.  Actually, good chance this game will fold, since the developer is in bankruptcy.

If you like Shadowrun PnP game and turn-based combat you might like this game.
Get this game on a Big sale price or think of it as a donation.

reviewText:
I played and loved the Shadowrun Returns series but not enjoying Shadowrun Chronicles as much as SR.
This game completely pales in comparision to Shadowrun Returns series.  This game company has my money as a donation.

The only redeeming quality this game has is the multiplayer co-op quest playing, which Shadowrun Returns series does NOT have.  The thing is the multiplayer is laggy, buggy and has potential to crash or will quit if the game developer folds.

It is more challenging playwise soloing than SR, since you Don't have in-quest healing, do have lower hitpoints, limited armor and limited gear slots.  The shaman class is limited, so i have read.  Limited magic spells compared to SR.   Deckers do have more to do in combat, but not sure if there is in matrix runs.

Character creation is weird, you are given a sort of hybrid avatar, then you have to spend your earned karma points on what skills you want to make the avatar into a class.  Does have early job skill buffs choices.  Does have more alternate path skills to learn like lockpicking, demolishing, organ harvesting, but those do take points away from combat skills.  Has an Either / Or tiered system of picking skills.

Does have some better looking maps, npc and avatar than SR and has conversation voiceovers for avatars and npcs, with a Boston accent.

It is still in developement, maybe it will get better later.  Read more reviews, forum and wikis, then watch playthroughs on video.  Actually, good chance this game will fold, since the developer is in bankruptcy.

If you like Shadowrun PnP game and turn-based combat you might like this game.
Get this game on a Big sale price or think of it as a donation.

To put into perspective how much of an entertaining game this is, I've played the game for 34 hours of the 50 I've owned it for.

It's a perfect iteration of what turn-based strategy should be like.
In fact, stop reading this and just buy the game.
It's definitely worth it.
11/10.

I would really go as far as to say, while being one of the most simple Shadowrun games mechanic wise I feel like the addition of multiplayer and extra character customization with the large amount of player cosmetic options really goes a long way all on its own. Even if you are not really interested in playing cooperatively with other players on your shadowrun team, you can still play through the missions with a team of AI shadow runners of your choice.\n\nTo go into more details about how skills work in Shadowrun chronicles, each weapon type has its own skill helix" Two separate paths that you make choices from

If you enjoyed combat in XCOM, Jagged Alliance or similar games, you should be able to have fun with this one as well. Unlike these other titles, however, SRC has a stronger RPG factor in that you are closer" to the Shadowrunner you create

reviewText:
I've had extensive experience throughout the development of this game, having bought it the minute it showed up on steam and played throughout the early access/beta process. For me this is a very fun game to hop on and do a few runs with friends and then hop off again. Its very much a casual game.

It catches the feel of classic turn based combat very well in my opinion. Yes, it does not have things like overwatch or take cover/hunker down. According to the developers at one point they claimed that was intentional, and in truth any X-Com player knows that overwatch in particular is very easy to exploit so its understandable.

Its important to understand that though this is Shadowrun flavored and certainly catches the spirit of Shadowrun, that it is NOT Shadowrun ruleset. Things like skills and cyberware/essence are handled very differently in this game. Don't let that scare you though as the system they do use will still seam very familiar and it doesn't detract from the title for anyone but the most hardened Shadowrun purists.

To me the thing that most lets the game down right now is the chat system. Its SUPER basic and lacks things like the ability to PM other players, ignore people, or even just switch it off. The group chat is fairly buggy and overall its something that in a social game I would hope is a priority for them to improve apon. I'd also like to see some kind of queue system for quick joining in runs which would only improve on the hop in and have a run" feel the game projects.

Another negative for me is the voice acting. The main characters voice (for females anyways) is HORRIBLE. The accent and the acting. I get that its supposed to be a game set in Boston so credits for trying with the heavy Boston accent but its horrible to listen to on a daily basis especially with a nasally tone to it. Another thing I don't like is the fact that the story voice over takes into no account your skills
date: so if for example you play a decker you still get voice over of your character moronically not knowing what a grid access point was.\n\nOn a positive note I can't say enough about the character customization in this game. I loath to draw a parallel back to X-com but again it has that kind of depth of customization and honestly even shames many true "MMOs" in its ability to let you get your character looking unique and like you want it. Even this however is a bit let down to me by the limited number of character portraits so though you can make an amazing character sprite
recommended: the portrait for it will be cookie cutter and almost never match the character.\n\nStill as a launching point for a future series of modules and gameplay Shadowrun Chronicles is an excellent way to integrate multiplayer and the Shadowrun experience while maintaining a familiar style to the other Shadowun games and good turn based experience. I'd certainly recommend it to people
hoursPlayed: both fans of Shadowrun and people just looking for a casual
voteText: quick fun experience."

reviewText:
I'm finding the game gets blasted with a lot of undeserved hate on these reviews. If you were looking for a 'true' MMO; you'll be sorely dissapointed.
This game isn't, and I don't have the impression that it tries to be.

It's more of a ... turn based Borderlands. Grab 3 friends and go to town.
The plot is forgettable, and conversation between me and my friends tends to go something akin to 'Why are we trying to shoot fat orc lady again?' - 'I dunno, it's the ojective. Can you mark her so I can salvo, or should I take a potshot'? - 'I need to resummon a drone, but let the hacker mark if you need it!' aaaaand we're back off to gamespeek.

It's pretty unique on the market in that sense, it's a co-op turn based game that you can play with 4 people; but will have no problem playing with just 2 or 3 thanks to the henchman system.

Don't expect a full fledged MMO going in, grab a few friends who share your love for turn-based and go to town, you'll enjoy it.

reviewText:
Take Shadowrun Returns, simplify it, coop mode and you have this game. It has a lot of faults which I will list later but even so, if you liked Shadowrun and want to play it with friend(s) then I can recommend getting this, online aspect really brings in tons of fun(mostly).

Negatives:

- repetitive mission types and sometimes maps

- not enauf information about ingame stuff on the interwebs

reviewText: Shadowrun Chronicles - Boston Lockdown, how should I say it... It is simply a masterpiece, no other game is able to compare to its monumentally amazing aspects. Firstly, it boast a fanastical system from which you are capable of customising your character to fit your preference. As well as this, the gameplay features much to be enjoyed as it has a very pleasing skill system which has been simplified to be fitting for anyone who wants to get straight into the action. The ability to reset skill points on demand would be much appreciated. The missions are not groundbreaking although they do provide a lot of amusement especially with the game's integrated co-op mechanic, making it fun for the entire family. Sound design on components such as weapons and actions are favourable and suitable as for the voice acting, wew lad".\n\n"Overall I would rate it a 3/5" - Mojang"

reviewText:
It was clear that this game was going downhill when the Kickstarter team started back-pedaling on their plans, contradicting their earlier claims, and ran one of the most mis-handled campaigns since CLANG.

The gameplay is clunky and forgetable, with minimal custimization. Further, the game is setup so that you can become good at EVERY skill. Basically, like Skyrim without a level cap, you have nowhere to go but towards some ungodly singulariy. It's not about What will I specialize in?" but "What will I specialize in FIRST?". Sink enough hours in and you can max out every single skill tree.

Just... disappointment on every level."

reviewText: How to spoil a great license.\nJust no, absolutely no. Very very disappointing game. First of all, you need to stay connected all the time, even if you want to play single player... the character creation definitely sucks, poor mechanics, no depth, meeh graphics, no actual roleplaying, an uninteresting story, the voice acting is bad and dull, and horrible and... no real strategy here, very frustrating experience with a nonsense hardness, the chance of winning are based on luck and not in your skill. It is not well balanced, percentages without any sense (being in front of an enemy with a 40% success rate, flank it and still have a 40%. This is a common thing), bad technical decisions, not very fun (ok, you can enjoy, a bit, the strategy in co-op)... and of course this is not Shadowrun, this is a generic turn based combat game with the Shadowrun name attached on it to call the attention.\nThe developers have not known how to do it and still don't know. A promising game totally wasted. Many improvements needed to make it a game that worth your time and money.

reviewText:
Updated for Final Release.
Finally making its way through Early Access, a name change and several updates. Shadowrun Chronicles is now complete and handing out the nuyen and contracts like a mad Johnson. I am happy to say that the developers have finally brought this game to state that I can enjoy. Delivering a full game experience. With the ability to create a unique runner, skill sets, and up to 4 player co-op. Now while there is plenty of that has been improved and even fixed. There is still some areas that need a bit of shining. However that doesn't stop this from being a very enjoyable title. Using your crafted runner you will bring something unique to the mission. Rather that be guns, hacking, or maybe a little magic. The story of SRC is not as in-depth as its compatriots. Being mostly linear and devoid of RPG elements. The graphics are good enough, as is the aesthetic of cyberpunk. Although the zoom features lets you see the block like shapes of the characters. In all SRC is a game that Shadowrun fans can enjoy and includes a pivotal element that other Shadowrun games missed. Multiplayer. For this reason and more. You should check out Shadowrun Chronicles - Boston Lockdown

I made a video review to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!
https://youtu.be/Lh9NTleRBGk
I hope you enjoy!
Martyr

reviewText:
Perfect game for those that would enjoy a strong COOP experience.

Saddly the game mechanics are completely different then those of the Hairbrain Studio Shadowrun Series Mechanics.
- But all in all I keep wanting to play with real players in the story line more then with just the Henchmen you can hire.

Saddly I can't justify getting this game at full price for the Delux version simply because I got it at discount price through a HumbleBundle sale for less then $20 Dollars and for all its flaws was seemed just right for the cost.
- besides a portion of the money went to a charity in the process.

Any who back on topic.

As you can see from the video trailer and the screen shots on the store page the game looks interesting.
Pro's
- Can further Customize and cordinate your character wardrobe, once you collect the clothing during missions.
- 4 player COOP for the story and Challenges
- can be solo played
- Enjoyable with friends.

Con's
- Plenty of miss clicks have caused many miss-haps during combat
- - Player deselects weapon during combat and uses previously selected weapon/skill to engage enemy
- - Player if still has movement points can be accidently moved from cover into open ending turn with character moving to the action bar area where your weapon's and skills are located
- During COOP other players have to communicate through Text instead of a HUD display to assist in other players Cordinating with one another for targeting a single enemy in a crowded room can be troublesome.
- I collected around 48 pairs of Buckle Pants and I don't have any way to sell them or get rid of or sell the random loot in the outfit menu selections.

All in all I enjoyed the gaming experience with my friends and look forward to the next chapter installement for the story once its released.

reviewText:
When I first heard about this game, I figured that the bar would be set pretty high for it. Alas, it was not. After having played Shadowrun Returns, Dragonfall and Hong Kong, I have to say that I was not impressed.

The upgrade/skill/ability tree system felt pretty dumbed down and kinda underwhelming. The aesthetic gear/clothing was an interesting touch, but after a point I stopped caring about it. Though, the duplicate aesthetic items were both pointless and annoying.

As for strategy and tactics, it didn't feel like it was there. Although, I was expecting something along the lines of the last title with this game. Basically, load out with class types only mattered so much. If you didn't know what to expect, bring a decker and a ranged class along for certain. Especially if the mission had lots of machine/drone type enemies, and you chose to be a mage of anykind.

Definitely glad I got this when it was on sale for cheap. Between Black Friday and Cyber Monday, I believe.

reviewText:
Update

Lag has been reduced to normal levels, and there are far fewer connection difficulties. I have since encountered different issues, such as the weapon vendor having a blank screen no matter how many times I restart so that I can no longer progress my character's weapons. Now that I've gotten a chance to play the game I'm disappointed that the only benefit I get from being a hacker, or a lockpicker is the chance to get an extra pair of pants or a skimpy bikini. I started a couple of other characters as well, but there is very little variation between the them. Hackers are essentially crappy ranged attackers with a couple of stun abilities. Gameplay is still very much like other negative reviewers have described it, you'll fall asleep if you don't have a friend goading you into playing and keeping it lively. The best Shadowrun game is still on a cardtridge or a piece of paper, and maybe if gamers stop defending every piece of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• cashgrab that caters to their interests you'll get a quality game someday.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

This is the current experience.

*TRY* to log into or create a character, this might cause the connection to hang requiring any number of restarts. Some of your characters might be lost to you for hours on end.

Connect to your friend, sometimes spending hours wondering why your friend in the same room can't find your instance or mission lobby. When the server manages to find someone, it will still take forever while the connection hangs. During any of the loading processes, you may have to shut down the character and repeat the hellish login process.

Once you're in a mission, expect 2-60 seconds to have every single action recognized and processed by the server. Turns that should take 10 seconds will take 3 minutes. The sync time between players will be radically different, so don't expect your horrible experience to be equal. During loading times, watch the same worthless human filth or games journalists that recommended this game on Steam explain that 'this is normal' on an annoying general chat, because even though this is a bad single player game with awful multiplayer options, it was retooled from an even worse mmo. Although not long enough to have the benefit of a persistent world, or  a group-finding system other than spamming the general chat with LFG"
recommended: "SORRY I COULDN'T ACCEPT THE INVITE BECAUSE MY GAME CRASHED TEN TIMES".\n\nThe game itself is undeniably shallow but approaching mediocrity WITH a coop partner
hoursPlayed: and I won't waste any more time than that explaining it because you simply should not be buying this game."

reviewText:
Perfect game for those that would enjoy a strong COOP experience.

Saddly the game mechanics are completely different then those of the Hairbrain Studio Shadowrun Series Mechanics.
- But all in all I keep wanting to play with real players in the story line more then with just the Henchmen you can hire.

Saddly I can't justify getting this game at full price for the Delux version simply because I got it at discount price through a HumbleBundle sale for less then $20 Dollars and for all its flaws was seemed just right for the cost.
- besides a portion of the money went to a charity in the process.

Any who back on topic.

As you can see from the video trailer and the screen shots on the store page the game looks interesting.
Pro's
- Can further Customize and cordinate your character wardrobe, once you collect the clothing during missions.
- 4 player COOP for the story and Challenges
- can be solo played
- Enjoyable with friends.

Con's
- Plenty of miss clicks have caused many miss-haps during combat
- - Player deselects weapon during combat and uses previously selected weapon/skill to engage enemy
- - Player if still has movement points can be accidently moved from cover into open ending turn with character moving to the action bar area where your weapon's and skills are located
- During COOP other players have to communicate through Text instead of a HUD display to assist in other players Cordinating with one another for targeting a single enemy in a crowded room can be troublesome.
- I collected around 48 pairs of Buckle Pants and I don't have any way to sell them or get rid of or sell the random loot in the outfit menu selections.

All in all I enjoyed the gaming experience with my friends and look forward to the next chapter installement for the story once its released.

reviewText:
Pros:
- Solid co-op x-com combat (the only place I have found that strategy system in a co-op environment).
- Solid graphics (although not ground breaking some of the maps are just amazing, better than x-com, and the detail such as exploding windows in such is nice.)
- BEST community! ( only have about 17hrs at the time of writing this but EVERYONE I have run into in game has been nice and helpful. Alot even rollplay in chat during games, which adds to the environment).
- Shadowrun co-op

Cons:
- Its all about the combat (nothing else really takes place in this game, no side hacking like in other shadowrun titles. No talking your way out of situations like in the Hairbrain games, every mission is kick drek and take names. Possible a Pro for some people but I have noticed alot of complaining in forums about its lack of deversity).
- map variety (although as stated the map are amazing, having not completed the campaign I am already seeing repeated maps in storymode).
- Chat system is lacking (for a multiplayer game that requires grouping you can't whisper/tell people or even those on your friend list!)
- Singleplayer lacking (you have the ability to play the story singleplayer and multiplayer but the companions for singleplayer are lacking compared to other players making it difficult to solo and forcing people to play multiplayer).

Overall it doesn't follow Shadowrun PnP to much and it isn't one of the Hairbraine games so I think alot of people got down on it. However it is a great multiplayer x-com style co-op game that I am now sure I will be getting my return on in fun.

reviewText:
Shadowrun Chronicles is a fun tactical RPG. Note: this review is mostly relevant for the campaign. I haven't touched the end-game content yet.

Currently the game works best in Single Player. Most of the current player-base have end-game level characters, so playing pick-up Co-Op will make the missions way too easy. If you are playing with a friend of similar level, then Co-Op would be fantastic, but I haven't been able to try that.

The game plays like a simplified version of Shadowrun Returns, with elements of X-Com. Its not much of an RPG (no exploration, no branching dialog) but you do control one character through the campaign and can choose a progression and item selection. If you play alone, you bring along 3 other NPCs with you on missions. They level up automatically and it doesn't matter if they die.

This game is good if you like Shadowrun, and want something to play after having beaten all of HBS games. Most missions are under 30 minutes in length, so its a great game to play if you are short on time.

reviewText:
Having put a fair bit of time into the game on multiple characters, I've seen a few of the ups and downs SRC has had to handle and to be frank?  For what it is, it's a good game.  Now, I'd like to preface that with the statement that I've been following this game since it was announced some years ago, back when it was still called Shadowrun Online, when all the game really had to offer were a handful of unpolished missions and character options.  That said, it has come leaps and bounds in what can honestly be called a particularly ambitious project for a small studio like Cliffhanger, and you know what, I think they did a pretty good job all things considered.

Admittedly, they have had some stumbling blocks, from early launch lag issues to missing or broken items and even in some cases surprise gamebreaking bugs, but through all that their Dev team was very responsive to the community's questions and concerns and tried to maintain as much transparency as they could concerning their efforts to fix said issues.  Even after the fact, they tried to make reparations to to the community as a whole as an apology for the trouble, which, in my opinion, speaks very highly of Cliffhanger as a whole.

That said, and onto the game itself, its a hex grid, turn based isometric centered in the Shadowrun universe following the adventures of your shadowrunner through (for the sake of being spoiler-free) the events of what could be called the Boston Incident.

The story itself is creative and unique, and well written besides, with tolerable voice acting where it applies (though the Boston accent can get tiresome during subsequent playthroughs) and does stay loyal to the Shadowrun source material.  That said, and I can't emphasize this enough, the game is not a point-for-point match to the PnP source.  Certain liberties have been taken in regards to the game being both online and, well, being a game.  Certain facets in the PnP source are unfortunately absent, in as far as customization goes, and as of right now most missions center around a run-and-gun playstyle (meaning that no, there isn't a stealth option).  That said, what it delivers, it delivers very well in that the combat is well-polished, balanced, and fun, and the downtime inbetween missions does offer a lot of chance for backstory, worldbuilding, and customization.

Bear in mind, what I said about the game lacking certain aspects of customization doesn't mean that the game lacks in customization at all.  In fact, it offers a wide array of options, both practical and cosmetic, both at creation and that which can be earned through gameplay.  This includes items that can be used in missions, weapons, armor, various types of cybernetics and spells, and a wide array of skills and abilities.  It opens up a lot of tactical options and allows players to approach objectives from several angles, which, in some cases, is absolutely vital towards the success of any given mission.

Difficulty can vary from build to build, and while there's no expressly right" way to play
date: there is a certain limitation to the number of playstyles you can use.  That said
recommended: there are a lot of variations
hoursPlayed: so the limits to what you can do are pretty broadly defined.\n\nThe interface is fine for the format.  There aren't any outstanding bugs or issues at this iteration of the game and for the most part
voteText: it's very intuitive and easy to master.  Gameplay is in tradition turn-based format

reviewText:

reviewText:
IntroductionShadowrun Chronicles: Boston Lockdown is a turn-based tactical game that has a similar battling system to XCOM. It's part of the Shadowrun series, but doesn't really seem to fit in with the other games that where mad ein thsi series. It has it's good and bad points, one of the main points being the new 4 multiplayer co-op mode that adds a bit more depth to the game itself from the other games in the series.

GameplayShadowrun Chronicles: Boston Lockdown starts with a really nice character design screen. ou are able to design your character, it has a large variety of tools that you can use to make your character unique and what you want yiur character to look like. Unfortuantly, this customization isn't carried over to the AI that are with you, letting the game down a little bit, but not by all that much. It would've been nice to be able to fully be able to customize your entire team, but it's not possible in this game. The missions do start off rather well, you might get a feeling that you are playing in XCOM, but with a cyberpunk feel and many different characters. Although to start off with the missions seem to be nice and flexible, it does start to get that feeling of just being the same mission, but with a different location that you are in and different enemies that you have to kill. The weapons that you can equip on your character seem to be all nice, and they all seem to be different from one anther. But in actual fact all the weapons that you find aren't really all that great, you don't really get that satifaction when you find a weapon in this game. I would say that playing co-op with some friends on this game would definatley be recommened, just because your friends will probably bring along useful items and equipment rather than the AI. It also makes it run a lot faster than having to play single player with the AI running with you as well.

The graphics of the game are great, and what really helps the game pull itself back up from some of the negative things that I have listed above. The graphics of each area that you go into seem different from the last and gives you a new change of scenery throughout the game. The lighting and shadowing isn't really focused upon that much throught the game, but some points here and there did stand out to be rather nice looking and such.

Pros+ Fun Cooperative play
+ Great character customization
+ Nice Graphics
+ Trading Cards & Achievements

Cons- Samey sort of missions
- Not fully customizable squad

Result / Final thoughtsShadowrun Chronicles - Boston Lockdown is a fairly fun and enjoyable game. I would recommend playing it in short bursts of say 30 minutes - 1 hour, as you may get bored of the samey missions and not come back to the game. The graphics are well designed and the character customization is well done.

For more reviews on a wide range of games, go and follow Sometimes You Playing curator group here.

reviewText:
Tl;dr: Pretty bland game that doesn't really get the setting or mechanics right. Playable with friends.

I'm a fan of the Shadowrun setting and I liked Shadowrun Returns, so I thought this game should be fun as well with the ability to play co-op as well. Well, I was partly right, because it is pretty decent as long as you have someone to play with. The reasons I'm not recommending the game is:
- I'm a fair bit into the story, but shops never sell anything new so it feels like I'm just accumulating nuyen (money).
- Skill trees feel very bland and at higher levels you need tons of karma (xp) to advance in a seemingly pointless skill.
- Magic is done wrong. A pure mage can't really harm robots in this game, while in the game system there are plenty of spells to do so with. Also, troll mages seem to be the best choice, because they do more magic damage. No clue why.
- Speaking of magic, hit% is really weird. Often I can have a 90% chance to hit with an AoE-spell and still miss, and every time I miss the spell hits one or more friends instead. Like, why would I throw a manaball backwards just because I missed the particular tile I was aiming at? This is almost game-breaking at times.
- The further you progress, the more you realize that the developers were lazy and just reused the same levels over and over again. The only things that change are where and which mobs are placed.
- Story isn't really engaging, so far it's mostly been meh".

This being said
date: if you'd really like some (simple) turn-based shadowrun action together with a friend or two
recommended: go ahead. I'd recommend you to first look up some gameplay-videos on YouTube though and get the game on a sale."

Early Access Review

Actually I am pleasantly suprised at how addictive this game can be.
The things I like so far are:

*Easy to just get right into things, there is enough just in the storyline to spend quite a few hours upgrading skills, searching for loot, upgrading gear etc.

I recommend this game if you are on the fence or looking for a new MMO to time sink your life away.
Good fun.

reviewText:
The game is unfinished as of this review 7/12/15. I'm sure they think it is finished and will release DLCs for future updates.

If you think it would be fun to play a game like the SR Returns/Dragonfall series in multiplayer, this seems fairly appealing. The trouble is that everyone you will play with will be max level and trying to farm more skillpoints. Then when the story does end you're left to do the same. There is no true decking subgame. There are no custom missions or procedurally generated content, so the maps can get old pretty quick after you finish the story. Anything past the main story is very grindy and unrewarding.

Sadly, I cannot recommend this as more than a $5 sale purchase, even then, only if you love shadowrun and want to play something that will feel like a grindfest. 3/10

reviewText:
This is an awesome adaptation of Shadowrun. Really lots and lots of options for dressing up your character exactly how you want him to look. Trannie trolls, dapper elves, you name it.

Game systems are fun, non-linear progression trees with hard choices and party combo set ups. It's a turn based game best played with 2-4 players, and turns are simultaneous which makes the turns go fast. You can play it solo, and it's fun then, but more so with other people.

It's X-com meets Jagged Alliance that you can play with your friends.

There is no pvp yet, it's all co-op, but the developers promise a pvp mode in future updates.

As to my very own 3 star rating: it has swords, it has elves, and promises to have pvp in the future. I give it 2.5 stars out of 3. :)

P.S. First shadowrun computer game where making a character was a fun experience.

P.P.S. First week had some server-side input lag and a lot of reviews bash this game based on that. They fixed the problem. No input lag now. Come on in, the water is fine.

reviewText:
I was talked into buying this by my sister and her boyfriend. I wasn't really convinced at first, but when we started playing, it was actually great fun. We were usually playing together, so I can't tell how easy it is to build a group without knowing players IRL. But with a group leveling up together, it's a neat teamplay experience. Also, it's a game you can play together with your nongamer girlfriend, since you don't have to be a APM genius to play this game, as it's turnbased, and still face a decent challenge.

Positive:
*) Interesting Skill System
*) Diverse Teams pay off, covering each others weaknesses
*) Quick Gameplay, one mission usually takes only 20 minutes or something.
*) Challenging Gameplay: After the first few Intro missions, you quickly discover that charging in just gets you killed. The game rewards a commando-like gameplay, which I liked.
*) Interesting plot. The scale might be a little TOO grand, but maybe that's just me.
*) Very interesting characters. I really liked the dialogues, and I also have to really praise the voice actors at this point.
*) Going through the campaign once with my friends took me about 30 hrs, although we played a few missions twice when someone had to catch up. I think that's alright for a game that costs 20 bucks.

Negative:
*) The last few missions were too easy. You got a lot of fancy new skills and equipment, while the enemies didn't get stronger by an appropiate amount. (Thankfully, at least the very last mission was pretty hard again, and a good temporary end for the campaign.)
*) The Chat Window is really weird. If you close it, you can't chat with your teammates (and you can't open it with ENTER, just with the mouse). If you leave it open, it stops you from clicking on a considerable part of the screen.
*) If you happen to change to a different skill right as one of your teammates does something, the active skill will reset back. Which, when you don't notice it, is extremely annoying and often dangerous. (e.g. you're on a melee skill and wanted to switch to a ranged one, fail to notice it resetting back to melee, and suddenly you charge into a group of enemies.)

Generally, I learned to live with the above problems. Sometimes they even made for some very fun moments you could laugh about afterwards. Still think they could improve that, though.

TLDR:
Surprisingly fun game. Playing it with your friends is awesome. It's a bit like a good action movie.

reviewText:
This is a good game.  The people complaining it's not strategic enough either have not played very far, or want it to be an exact clone of X-Com.  Although there's no overwatch button that you're forced to press about 1000 times per mission, it has it's own mechanics that make it interesting.  The game's storyline is not going to win any awards, but by the end I did want to know what would happen.  You can also click past all the dialogue if you choose to.

Shadowrun fans will be surprised to learn that Decking now does damage in the meat space.  However, after some thought, this makes sense both for gameplay and for lore purposes.  Throughout the game, the story seems to assume that datajacks now wireless and that every metahuman has one, two assumptions that would have been far-fetched in 1980s, but are obvious to today's cell phone culture.  Since wireless networks are inherently capable of peer-to-peer connections, I think it's actually logical that IC damage could happen even without connecting to the (server-based) matrix.  Of course, from a gameplay perspective, standing around while the team's decker entered the matrix would be pretty boring, so the changes are also necessary to make Shadowrun multiplayer.

For those who prefer single player experience: My Rifle/Decker character was able to complete the entire main story and all side missions with no grouping; only the post-game challenge mission requires grouping.  Some missions were a little tough, so there are probably some character builds that would require grouping for the main game.

For first time players: You will have enough experience points, money, and weapon slots to choose two of the main damage ability trees: Shotguns, Handguns, Automatics, Blades, Blunt, Spellcasting, Summoning, Decking (Hacking), or Rigging (using robotic drones).  For those learning the game, I recommend you choose Automatics or Shotguns for one of your two skills, and whatever you want for the second.  You could also pair Hacking with Spellcasting or Summoning, or Rigging with Spellcasting.  Don't pick both melee skills, both magic skills, or both minion skills (Rigging and Summoning), at least until you know what you're doing.

reviewText:
After playing the game through to the end a few times now, i do like the potential this game offers, though there is still much that could be done to improve it:

- No trading as of yet, would be really nice to trade some of the rarer gear doubles i have for the pieces i actually want, i would like to see either player to player trading or a vendor you can exchange your good gear drops (from challenges) for the pieces you havnt been lucky enough to get.

- The combat is good though i find myself missing constantly but at the same time find myself causing critical hits just as often, the luck component in the combat does make for some really interesting kills/deaths.

- End game is a dead end, after you finish the story and the new infection missions, your only choices are to find another player who isnt maxed you can help through the story, make a new runner, or do challenges, being only two challenges they start to get boring.

All in all the game is really fun and i find myself playing it every day, it really does emulate shadowrun nealry perfectly, and im sure the game will continue to take off thought please, add in that trading, and maybe some single player stuff for end game, challenges were not meant to be done with the henchmen :)

reviewText:
Shadowrun Chronicles offers the next generation of tactical turn based action games. Blending X-Com style gameplay with RPG elements.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DQnv--4rvJA

Entrapped in a city plagued by a deadly virus, assaulted by the minions of a megacorporation, attacked by infected and with a dragon on a rampage through the city you have to unearth the secret conspiracy that connects it all.

As the leader of your team of Shadowrunners, you will have to use magic, technology and every weapon available to you, to save the lives of thousands in a city at the brink of extinction. Grow you character, plan your missions and control your team in combat or play live co-op with other players to overcome the challenges ahead of you. Meet your fellow runners in the Back Alley or hire henchmen to help you succeed.

Set in the dystopian near future of our world, where magic has awakened and blends with technology, creatures of myth and legend have returned. Elves, Dwarves, Orks and Trolls walk among the neon-lit streets, while the matrix connects everyone and everything as the corporate towers cast their long shadows across the globe. You are a Shadowrunner - a secret operative on the edge of society, hired for the jobs no one wants to be connected with. A cyberpunk rebel surviving by skill and instinct in the shadows of the corporate towers!  - Highly Recommended!

reviewText:
Overall, great game. I picked this up during the Steam summer sale and have highly enjoyed it. I'm a fan of turn-based RPGs in general and this has been a fun addition. A few details:

Character: I've tried a trio of characters at this point. It's a classless system, and different builds allow for a nice selection of playstyles.

reviewText:
I came to Shadowrun relatively late only in 2013 when the video game franchise has been rebooted with Shadowrun: Returns. Since then I became a huge fan of the series and played all released PC games so far, including Shadowrun Chronicles: Boston Lockdown.

I especially fall for the title made by Cliffhanger Productions due to its online/multiplayer feature. It is a really great experience so far and I must admit that I got addicted a bit recently.

Let me summarize Shadowrun Chronicles: Boston Lockdown:
It's a classic turn-based strategy (TBS) game like XCOM (as often mentioned), Warhammer 40,000: Chaos Gate or the rebooted Shadowrun game series made by Harebrained Schemes and unifies the best aspects of all mentioned TBS games. Its simple controls and game basics on one hand and its partly very challenging combats and missions on the other hand are in sum appealing to both, 'old hands' and rookies. A bonus are the RPG elements and the skills system, which are similar to Harebrained Schemes' Shadowrun games, but slightly rearranged. Right now, there are already wide possibilities of skills and skill combinations, e.g. decker, rigger, shotguns, blades, blunt, shaman etc.

The game mechanics are based on the fifth edition of the Shadowruns tabletop game and its very potent licence, meaning if you're into cyberpunk, science fiction, dystopia and love the Shadowrun universe, this game is for you.

Unfortunately, there are some drawbacks as well. Even though there are relatively much missions to play, lot of them are short or seem kinda inconsistent story wise. In general lacks the story in excitement and depth and gains momentum only late in the story progress. Therefor, some side missions are really interesting and challenging and a lot of fun (but are taking place on recurring maps of the main campaign though).
The missions are more fun in cooperative multiplayer with fellow 'Chummers', but sadly it can take quite a while before you get fellow players together since the game is a little depopulated currently. In other words, you are depending on prebuilt henchmen sometimes, whose character development you cannot affect or control. Thus, they are a little 'underpowered' but should be enough powerful for the main story campaign.
The interaction with other players is also kinda awkward, since there is no direct chat (whispering) implemented and basically there are only two chatrooms in total existing; the global chat and the party chat if you teamed up with other players. This can be a bit annoying sometimes but is still to handle.

Good thing is the developers still add content to the game and have much plans for the future. The support by the game developers, Cliffhanger Productions, is outstanding; very curteous and extremely kindly (and fast!).

That's why I rate this game positive. Again: if you're into Shadowrun, TBS and Fantasy, support the devs and that hidden gem and buy it!

My judging:

4.5/5

reviewText:
SRR and its cadre were made by a bigger team with a much-bigger budget and more time to really flex. That being said, while Cliffhangar has worked their asses off and spent many sleepless nights slaving away, having the same expectations for SRC that you have for SRR is going to disappoint you.

Does that mean SRC sucks? Not at all. I quite enjoy it, and I invite you to see my profile for the hours I've put into this and the Returns series. If you are a big fan of the Shadowrun lore and universe, I'd be surprised if you didn't like this one.

This game does require a perpetual Internet connection, even if you're playing with NPC henchmen. The online aspect of this game is amazing and really helps prevent the ho hum doing this kind of mission again" burn-out you might feel. We have quite a few character slots so you're free to explore different characters. The cosmetic options are pretty flexible and certainly helps capture the eclectic look of shadowrunners.

some tripple-a titles even fail to deliver here.

What I did not like
- The original Shadowrun game is a roleplaying game with turn based fights as one aspect. Shadowrun Croncicles reduces the whole Shadowrun experience to the round based tactic part of it. "Shadowrun Returns" did a way better job transpoting the SR story/rpg elements to the player by implementing dialog decissions and dialog options based on skills. ShadowRun Chronicles is like what Final Fantasy Tactics was for the Final Fantasy franchise. reviewText:
Ring Side Report-Video Game Review of Shadowrun Chronicles: Boston Lockdown

Originally posted at www.throatpunchgames.com, a new idea everyday!

Product- Shadowrun Chronicles: Boston Lockdown
Producer- Cliffhanger Productions
Price- $25 here http://www.shadowrun.com/shadowrun-online/
TL; DR- An ok game, but overshadowed.  80%

Basics-It's never just a milk run.... In Boston Lockdown, you take the roll of a shadowrunner who wakes up on a metal slab.  How did you get there?  Why did a dragon destroy the Red Sox playoff hopes?  Take the roll of any kind of shadowrunner you want, hit the matrix, shoot straight, and never, ever, deal with a dragon.
Mechanics- There isn't much here in the game, but it works decently. Players get to choose a race and select how they want to build their character.  But, there isn't a whole lot there.  The races give a bit of a difference at character start, but don't really change the game all that much.  You get a couple of powers that you will use through your archetype all the way through the game.  You increase the powers by training up a simple skill tree.  That's fine, but you don't really get a ton of depth from that.  Once you have your powers, that's in!  Don't expect a ton of difference between a start character and a character that finishes the game.  You're numbers a bigger, but that's really it.  In terms of game play, the game is a simple tactical game.  You're team of characters takes their turn moving and shooting/using powers, then the bad guys go.  That is every single mission.  You might get a mission to defend a location for a bit or touch X number of switches on the map, but overall it's the same mission over and over again.  Again, not bad, but you won't spend 10 hours playing this game.  It's fun for a short burst, but then you'll put it down and do something else.  It's a semi-solid B effort. 4/5

Theme- Here is the saving grace of the game-This is Shadowrun 2075!  You're playing modern Shadowrun set in the same universe as all the current books.  Wiz!  If you want to see how the world story is changing, then you're going to play this game.  The story is fun and fresh.  It does have the standard milk run to major plot" clich√© we know and love
date: but it does get its foot in the door.  4.5/5\n\nExecution- If the theme is good
hoursPlayed: then the execution is the bad.  This game is lag-tastic.  I have a laptop and a desktop that can both run some pretty hardcore
voteText: taxing games
helpfulPercent: but this game lags on both.  There aren't even that many people on screen
votesHelpful: and the game lags.  Forgiving lag
votesTotal: the game feels kind of half done.  It's a working finished product
votesFunny: but some characters get a voice
commentsCount: and some don't.  Why?  Stick to all voice or all text
column16: as it feels like the budget run out halfway through this part.  The controls are semi-intuitive
column17: so that's ok
column18: but the learning curve can cost you some money in the beginning.  The fact you only really get two powers for the whole game doesn't really make me think leveling up the character is important.  It's not a horrible game by any means; it just feels like it's not completely finished.  3.5/5\n\nSummary-There are two major Shadowrun computer games coming out now: the online game and Shadowrun Returns.  This is where it gets hard.  Shadowrun Chronicles isn't a bad game
column19: but compared to Shadowrun Returns
column20: it's not the best.  Honestly both games tend to get a little same-y as every level is a tactical encounter with little roleplaying
column21: but Returns beats Chronicles on that front.  What Chronicles has that Returns doesn't is the current world/metastory and co-op.  That's what has its hooks in me.  I'm a sucker for a shared world I can influence
column22: and this one has it in spades.  So the honest summary-if you only have $25 to spend and need a great introduction to Shadowrun-buy the RPG ebook (Didn't see that one coming did you?!).  However if you need a video game
column23: then you should hands down get Dragonfall and Shadowrun Returns.  If you want an online experience with leveling and co-op with friends with some current Shadowrun story
column24: then Shadowrun Chronicles is a good place to play.  Neither beat the tabletop experience
column25: but Chronicles will at least let you game with some friends.   80%\n"

reviewText:
This game has simple but aesthetically pleasing graphics, nice character outfit customization with a large variety of items (gotten at random from missions) and gameplay which is easy to learn but can be hard to master. It's turn-based strategic shooting in the same vein as Fallout Tactics or Xcom, though with less focus on the story aspect.

The game has its faults, chief among them the chat system which at this time offers no way to communicate privately with other players, as well as frequent disconnections from the servers which ejects you from the game entirely. However despite this, the enjoyment factor is extremely high and the game is never more fun than when you have four players in the same experience range taking on a mission together.

The co-op element, whether you are two players with a NPC each or a full team of four, really makes me happy with this purchase. And as it stands, this is my favourite co-op game of the year (and in several years). If assembling groups was a bit easier, the communication more streamlined and the characters a little more customizable, it would a must-own title.

As-is, I would recommend to to anyone who likes tactical co-op or shadowrun/sci-fi.
For anyone else it might be a gamble.

reviewText:
It's certainly not the best Shadowrun, or the best squad-based tactics game. However, if you have played all the other good ones and don't expect much, it can still be an enjoyable game. There isn't much here other than the battles, but fortunately they are still fun enough to feel worth it, especially if you can get a good deal on the game. I recommend to fans of the genre if they have played through games like XCOM and Shadowrun/Dragonfall enough already.

+Gameplay - combat-oriented turn-based squad tactics, simple and fun, quick to action
+Main story and side missions to follow
+Visuals - backgrounds / character models look good and are varied
+Variety of customizable clothing/accessory/appearance options, changeable between missions
+Voiceovers - even your own character is voiced

-Story doesn't really draw you in, doesn't really 'feel' very Shadowrun in story or mechanics
-Out of 4-5 characters on a mission, only your main char is created/customizable
-Skills feel very limited, very few spell choices
-No social skills / important dialogue choices
-Several minor annoyances/glitches, very few in game options

reviewText:
Review Update 5/12/15

With the lag problem now fixed I wanted to update my review of the game. A more detailed review to come after I have had a chance to put more time into the game.  For now I have changed the recommendation from no to yes, as I am having fun playing the game right now, and Steam doesn't offer any third option yet.



The game is fun but flawed. It is a turned-based co-op game with parties between 2-4 characters with an addition 2 summoning slots for drones and spirits. You can fill out the party slots by hiring henchmen that you will control, by finding other people to join you on a mission, or a combination of both.  My experiences with the community have been great, always willing to answer questions I have and I have not had any problems finding people to join me on missions.  Most of flaws in the game come mostly from the game feeling rushed out of Early Access with parts of the game feeling incomplete or unfinished.   One big plus for the game is the Dev's are still working on the game and have been active in the community and seem to be listing to suggestions,

My main problems with the game right now.

1. No whisper or private chat in game. There is no way to talk privately to your friends or just to discuss anything with community members.  So have fun filling the global chat with anything you want to talk about. I shouldn't say no way, you can invite them to your group to chat, but that is only if you are not already in a mission and your group isn't full.

2. A lack of information in the game. There is a lot of stuff in the game that is never explained to you in game, and a lack of documentation makes some things very frustrating.  Some examples of this are in the perks you choose. Some will clearly start you will receive a 10% increase to damage or critical hits, where as others will only tell you that you will receive a boost to damage or crit, but never how much of a bonus.

3. No looking for group tool or chat. There is no way to find a group to join, or find members for your mission except to keep calling out in the global chat.

4. PVP focus of the game has Cliffhanger making poor design choices.  This game is focused on PVP, which is not even in the game yet, and because of that they have made a number of poor design choices too keep parity in the classes, rather than focus on a good co-op game.  An example of this is Rigger and Decker  have just been turned into magic users with the Rigger being a Shaman that summons" drones instead of spirits
date: and the Decker is now a mage that cast "tech" spells to attack the enemy (yes
hoursPlayed: Decker magic). The Rigger will also compete with any Shaman on your team for a summon spot

reviewText:
The game is fun and it has potential.

However I can't say that I'd recommend this game to someone. The balancing of the game nerfs the team cannot have rigger and other summoners on the same team, cannot deploy multiple riggers. Theres a lack of bad guys you fight most of them are simple gunners. Next is the lack of ability to revive a teammate, a teammate goes down and you have 5 turns to finish the mission and escape. This is not how shadowrunners work in the RPG a guy goes down you get the job done regarudless. There also seems to be a lack of ability to revive a someone after they go down. Medkits or the basic ability to heal you or yourteam mates have to be found and your limited to 2 of them per run. I'd rather a weight system, I can only carry two medkits but I have cybernetic limbs... which is silly. I think if they work on the balancing it could be a lot of fun. Yes 4 riggers could swarm a map, so put the ability to hack drones in so they loose the drones.. you swarm with 4 riggers and your going to be in a world of hurt.

reviewText:
I purchased this game solely for single-player play. I have not played and will not play any multiplayer. I have played through the entire game once with a pistol/blades elf. I don't regret playing it and generally had fun, but there are some major shortcomings. I won't be replaying or buying any DLC.

PROS:
1) Turn-based squad combat is fun.
2) Even if rather limited, it is set in the Shadowrun universe. There is no substitute for that.
3) Character customization is pretty well done.

CONS:
1) Requires login to servers to play and you are forced to see the global chat.
2) No choices to be made in the story until the very end. You can choose not to do side missions, but those are just inconsequential grinding for money and experience.
3) Writing was boring and lifeless. Didn't use contractions.
4) Weapon progression seemed silly. You save up a bunch of money waiting for new weapons and armor in the shop and then buy the best new weapons an armor. Thing is, you don't even know what you are saving up for until it's available and once it is, you can probably just buy everything you want immediately.
5) No documentation
6) No Matrix
7) Deckers doing damage to everything short of magical creatures with their deck seemed silly.
8) Mages not having access to a physical attack seemed like an artificial limitation.
9) Henchmen (NPC runners) can only have single offensive skill. This made melee henchmen nearly useless. You need to use cover in this game and it is not easy to do that if you have to get up close to contribute at all.
10) Henchmen can't have tactical items (e.g. medkits)
11) No overwatch capability
12) Wild camera movement during enemy turn makes it hard to see damage amounts as they appear
13) Lots of map reuse. You can start me at a different end of the map, but it's still the same map.
14) Missions started to feel very formulaic. I began using the same set of henchmen for every mission (Halon, Bats###, and Jimmy Mac). Cover, mark, fire, slice, rinse, and repeat.
15) Every character gets two actions per turn and attacking ends the character's turn. Unless you get a temporary bonus, you can't just attack twice. You can't attack and then reload. You can't attack and then run for cover. This felt so limiting, simplistic, and artificial.

reviewText: This game is a very tough Tactical Strategy game and that is a great thing. I love the setting and enjoy the feel of it and some missions trial and error choices are very interesting to try to run through. The gameplay is solid, the artstyle is beautiful, and I love that it is set in Boston and makes constant references to that effect which is a personal bias but it is a plus.\nWhy don't I recommend it though?\nThe servers are absolutely awful, there doesn't seem to be many people on them and despite playing a lot of missions without other players in the world, there is a tremendous amount of lag. Sometimes it takes a full minute for an action to carry out leaving you to wonder if you actually clicked the mouse button or not. If this gets rectified, I will definitely change my review to a thumbs up and would love to play the co-op with friends.

reviewText: I bought this game during it's early access stage back in February (Yay taxes!), and I've watched it grow since then. I would pop in and out from time-to-time to see the companies' progress. I have to say, I am truly impressed with how far this game has gone. reviewText:
Shadowrun Chronicles - Boston Lockdown is one of those games that I can only describe as 'barely enjoyable'.

The game isn't very well made... There are issues with the core gameplay (skills and abilities versus cost), level design (very repetetive and unimaginative) and usability/UI (unresponsive UI in multiplayer, prone to misclicks, etc). I don't get the impression that these devs know what they are doing (just look at the discussion regarding respecs).

Still, co-op multiplayer manages to entertain. Simply do one run per evening with a friend and you might get some enjoyment out of this, play more and you would be frustrated. All in all I wouldn't recommend buying this game unless it is below EUR 10.

reviewText:
Things I like:
- the combat system; turn-based fits this perfectly, 2 actions/turn works well in keeping things challenging but still leaving every mission possible to complete.
- the leveling system; you can have any combination of primary/secondary weapons. EXP is not earned through killing, but instead through completing missions.

Things I dislike:
- Skill trees are too simplistic.
- You cannot trade items with other players.
- You cannot trade money with other players.
- You cannot sell extra pieces of clothing.  (Why do I need 5 of the same top?!)
- It's neat that in a 2-person party you get to each add a character on 4-man missions from the available runners for hire.  It sucks that some missions give you additional NPCs on top of that to control, and they're all under the control of the party leader.  If you're not the party leader you can be waiting for them to move up to 4 characters (including their own) and any summons they've got as well.  Kind of boring.
- You see the same maps over and over.
- You do the same quest over and over...just with a little extra story flavor, and on a different map then last time.  Go protect a 2x4 area of this map."  "Go protect a 3x3 area of this map."
- Very linear storyline.  No reason to play again after beating the game.
- There should be a confirmation message when buying things instead of the game just taking your money.
- Why can't I instantly resell something I've bought on accident for full price?  I haven't left the store.  Why do I only get 1/10 the price I paid back?
- The voice acting is kind of annoying.  Why doesn't every shop npc have a voice?

It's a fun game
date: but I don't ever see myself playing it again once I've completed it."

reviewText:
Shadowrun Chronicles is a decent attempt at making a heavily multiplayer focused turn based strategy game and to some extent it does succeed, but unfortunately for me it's failures heavily outweigh it's innovations.

----

+ Unique in that the turn based tactical gameplay is fully co-op.

+/- Gameplay can be fun, but is shallow compared to other similar games (see the other Shadowrun games, XCOM, Massive Chalice, Final Fantasy Tactics, Tactics Ogre, Front Mission, Fire Emblem, etc)
+/- Costume collecting elements exist, but many of them are very similar to each other

- Terrible story telling
- Wonky, nonsense filled dialogue
- Terrible voice acting
- Very little end game content without DLC
- No matchmaking other than spamming global chat
- The same battlefields are used multiple times
- Outside of missions, you are restricted to one small and boring hub area for the whole game.
- Some minor bugs and strange design choices give the game a slightly broken feeling

----

This is probably not the shadowrun game you are looking for. This is not a part of the other more popular Shadowrun series which is also on steam and which I would highly recommend.

First off, I am a complete sucker for turn based tactical games of this nature. I absolutely can't get enough of them. The idea of being able to play a game like that with some buddies is an intriguing one to say the least. I am grateful this game exists, if only for the possibility that more games might attempt a similar formula and hopefully do it much better.

Sadly though, there may be a story in Shadowrun Chronicles, but other than there being a lockdown in Boston in which you and your pals are stuck, i'm really not sure what it is. There's some nonsense about increasingly stupidly named corps" (the big corporations which are the social leaders in the shadowrun universe) being up to no good in some vague way and there are AI zombies and dragons involved somehow. That's about all I was able to gleam from the ridiculously inept story telling and confusing
recommended:
the voice acting made it difficult to concentrate for any length of time on what was being said. My orc character seemed to me like the voice was copied straight from the normal human male and pitch shifted down with some cheap software. It really sounded awful.

The game quickly devolves then into a series of pointless missions that go on for just a tad too long before culminating in a boss fight so difficult that the universally accepted way of beating it involves hiding in a small room for long periods of time.

Overall
hoursPlayed: it's not a game I would recommend to anyone but the most die-hard of Shadowrun fans or turn based tactical connoseurs
voteText: and even then I would only recommend it with the affidavit that it is mostly not very good."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm fairly disappointed.

Now, let's start with the good. Models and graphics are pretty good, actually -- ragdolls are nicely done, too. Visually, this game is decent. Soundtrack and setting tend to reflect the universe very well! It's almost like a throwback to Shadowrun Returns for me, especially with the organ mission.

The game itself feels clunky and customization fairly limited. Where I looked at my character in Shadowrun Returns and even Dragonfall, and was in love, I couldn't quite say the same. Understandably, the skill trees have been condensed and simplified, but it doesn't help someone who came from one game where it felt like having complete say in a character to one of the same setting and having very, very little. Comparatively, there's little -- if any -- attachment to the lore or setting. All of it seems very arbitrary. All in all, not worth the $29.99 charged, but also not a terrible game in its own right. I do wish I had tried something else, though.

So far, for early access -- not bad. Not bad, but not very encouraging. I'm hoping things develop more along the way.

If that's all you want... then wiz... this game is for you.  If you want ACTUALLY Shadowrun, then you're drek outta luck - just geek this game now and wait for Shadowrun Hong Kong, because this is NOTHING like shadowrun, other than combat only.

reviewText:
I bought this game because I really like Shadowrun: Dragonfall. I regret it. This thing is terrible.

First:
There's no tactical depth. You cannot set your guys to overwatch. You can't even bloody shoot and then move (it's move and then shoot only). This results in a game where your 'tactical' options consist of blandly moving from cover to cover and tossing dice at enemy soldiers. Is it hard"? Sure. You'll take a crit to the face and be decked. HP is so low and healing options are so limited that that'll probably be it for you. But is there any strategy to it? Very
date:
very little. This isn't XCom or Dragonfall and options are too limited to make it a true tactical experience.

Second:
The story is rubbish. You don't get dialogue or roleplaying choices
recommended: just some (horribly acted) dialogue that strings together some incredibly mundane and uninspired missions. "Go here and shoot these guys for some contrived reason". I like the Shadowrun universe
hoursPlayed: but if you're going into this expecting to find anything resembling the Glory side story from Dragonfall
voteText:
then prepare for disappointment.

Third:
There's no enemy variety. For the first few hours of this game all you are fighting are shirtless dwarves with baseball bats and dogs. You could at least change the colour of the dogs or something guys. Everyone also uses the same sound file
helpfulPercent:
so expect to kill a bunch of female enemies that grunt like men when you drop them. Talk about lack of polish.

Fourth:
The game is plagued by bad design
votesHelpful: bugs and lag issues. Take a look at the community hub and see the company begging for forgiveness. It's pathetic and these guys clearly weren't ready for go-time. I've had to Alt-F4 out of the game multiple times because I joined the party while talking to someone.  Sometimes I'll use a skill and have it go into cooldown and nothing will happen. You can moan about this being the first week of release or whatever
votesTotal:
but that doesn't make any of this ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• close to being acceptable.

Fifth:
Every time a mission ends
votesFunny: you have to spend a minute slogging back to a green 'mission complete' zone to end it. This is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing tedious and makes me sick.\n\nAll in all: This game is about a year of design away from being even remotely good. Do not buy it

reviewText:
Why must we be online to play this game in solo ?
The previous Shadowrun titles were not online and were great !
This episode of Shadowrun would also be great without all the issues caused by the fact it is online (terrible lag, disconnexions, impossibility to log on, annoying chat visible onscreen... and soon PvP).
Dear Devs, if you want to allow people who like that to play in group online, that's fine with me, but please don't force people who prefer to play offline to play online !
Isn't it obvious that offline versions of games are always better than online versions because the need to use a 'middleman' (game server) can only slow the game and cause login/reboot troubles ? And I don't even talk about the risk to not anymore being able to play a game if the editor decide to stop the server because it's not enough used anymore or because they go bankrupt.
All those issues don't exist on offline game...
So, even if I loved to play this game (except the final mission which is way too difficult), I don't recommend to buy it only as a form of boycott to discourage devs to do games that force you to play online.

reviewText:
It's not what I expected, and it's far away from what was announced on the promo videos. There's no legwork, the interactivity of deckers and mages with the elements of the map is so poor (well, for mages there isn't any as long as I know), the coop missions is just to repeat previous missions once and once again... And then there's the 20 daily server restarts due to technical and lag issues, which is funny because this is a heavily instanced game with not so many players to justify these problems. The current state of the game is a bad copy of Shadowrun Returns, with poorer mechanics (for example, no matrix gameplay) and story. It looks like they took away all the interesting points when they changed the name. I hope it gets better soon, or it will have a really sort life. reviewText:
Siempre he sido un fanboy de Shadowrun, pero me temo que Chronicles: Boston Lockdown no lo puedo recomendar. A nivel de jugabilidad, reduce las cuatro fases de un run (encuentro con el Johnson, legwork, infiltraci√≥n y pago) a b√°sicamente una (infiltraci√≥n); a mayores, incluso esta fase le han quitado todos los aspectos de contacto, planificaci√≥n y sigilo, dejando solo un juego de estrategia por turnos que, en realidad, es una copia cutre de XCOM. A mayores, aunque los no roleros no lo noten, se salta por completo la mec√°nica de juego del juego de rol, ignorando cosas como que la matriz es wireless o que los esp√≠ritus no se invocan x turnos sino por servicios. Al final, por todo ello, la personalizaci√≥n de las clases es bastante menor de lo que deber√≠a ser. El coop opcional no lo salva, la verdad.

Junto a esto, a nivel gr√°fico tampoco se salva. Shadowrun es un universo oscuro y cyberpunk, dist√≥pico y con muchas sombras... no un despliegue de colores con estilo cartoon. Y no s√≥lo a nivel de texturas y dem√°s, sino el dise√±o de los personajes es en la mayor parte del tiempo rid√≠culo. A nivel de sonido el juego cumple sin alardes, la m√∫sica lo mismo, y no tiene voces dobladas.

El resultado es un juego que podr√≠a haber dado mucho pero no lo da. No s√≥lo no llega a la altura del juego de rol sino que, como videojuego, ni siquiera puedo decir que sea bueno. Un 4.

reviewText:
tl;dr version

fun? = meh

story? = disappointing~ just felts like emotionless dialog... it stoles my smile... no joke :|
i always love to immerse myselfs into any artist's story and i always appreciate their creative expression through the passion they puts into their work, but i couldn't finds much if any at all in this title...

co-op? = didn't get to do any~ there's no basic group functions for a fun quick slap together PUG play =\nshouting LFG class blahblahblah~ wtf is this the 90's

=======

first offs this is one of my big rant reviews of thoroughly giving a game a good chance and trying my absolutes hardest to stay positives abouts it while trying my best to really enjoy the product and share to you my view on a game from someone with 25+ years gaming experience, a modder, an old school pen&paper RPG making creator, with a few classes or so of university experience in the game developement industry, games are my life, it's what i do.  however my outlook is one of a retired pro gamer that wants to relax~ i'm not a casual gamer, my casual relaxing = your hardcore~

i've gotten burnt outs over the years for most genres, but i do appreciate hard work on games from the devs cuz i know how much work every little thing needs to work in a game... i'm no stranger to the game developement process.  i have a mechanical mind as well as a very artistic~like creative view on things.  i appreciate art, and understand the work and effort one goes through in making it, along with the mechanical knowledge of how things work from models, textures, codes, pathing, etc....  i may not fully know every single possible detail, but i have a very good knowledgable understanding to appreciate and admire all the effort that goes into every little thing in a game.

i thought this game woulda had more done with basic gameplay functions by now after all this time... why not storyline quest reward respec karma once, can't earn agains and be dones with its~ no freakin' respec willy nilly but you still gets one to redo your mistakes.  i started this game thinking all the abilities would behave similar to shadowrun returns, but it's nothing like that, and i'm tired of remaking my character over and over again with no respec in sight, seeing threads from 2014/2015 waaaaaaaay back saying it on wishlist or somethings and never ever doing it at all.  no character sheet or quest log window key like really... lol basic stuff.  a lfg party matcher woulda been basic stuff too~ i mean we're not in the early 2000's anymores lol these are really basic things for an online mmo~ish game =/ makes me sad cuz i was looking forward to playing a shadowrun game agains, but the slow developement on basic things is very disheartening.

i dunno how much trouble unity is giving the devs, but when i look at the horrible UI functions, it makes me wanna just go play something else cuz it gives the image that the studio isn't doing well, and when i asked if there was a key for charactersheet/quests day1 get snappy attitude from some guy, ok not a good way to attract new costumers to the game if that's what this games small playerbase is likes =\ i thoughts being an older rpg from the old days woulda attracted more of the older nicer peoples from the old days of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ming, not more of the typical bad child~like attitudes you see everywhere else :|

i spents hours playing already, looking for a respec on google to see @what mission i can expect to earn my one free respec to ease my mind, that i EXPECTED to be there like all mmo's have after finishing a story or somethings you know.  like every mmo in existence has :| playthru game unlock costume thingies, etc.etc. finds that i don't enjoy my initial weapon selections as much as i wanted and saw these cool things like spellcasters fling powerful energy thingies and stuffs, and i wanted to just go into mage after giving it a longer lookovers... but nothings after all this time =( really... just puts it as a one time quest reward for storyline devs... seriously nots hard.  one time reward... it just a few lines of extra code not much lol sigh.

game needs some serious rebalancing too, one background way OP compared to another... stuff like that, no custom colored items, etc. etc. i dunno if unity has any material files or nots but the balancing for a turn based RPG likes this, it not hards lol not for a number based dice roll rpg game like this... i do it all the time =\ on paper for pen&paper RPG games like D&D, RIFTS, etc. , i studied those games like crazy back in the day, i literally finds how to min-max in pen&paper RPGs and balance it outs easily, doing 100+dmg in D&D for examples per swing lol, i mod games, i know what coding can be like i've been to college for it.  putting in a new window, assigning a key, and placing some basic value checks like what quests the player has available in the mission map, or a character sheet that displays even just a tad more info on yourselfs... more portraits i mean seriously like 5 portraits for female elf and human has like 12, but why so little after all these years... it's not a big picture... shoulds has like literally has at least 50 different portaits per race&sex by now.  it was a kickstarter game right?  did the devs ever reach outs to the community for aid.  i sure some gamers would've loved to make their own art or something for portaits or whatever you know.  you'd be surprised what a community for a game can do if you asked them.  i've seen some amazing things created in my years of gaming since the 90's

i want to like the game, i really do, but in it's current state~ it's not very friendly to new costumers, especially ones that don't know shadowrun very well.  even to those that know a little from other titles and kinda has an idea what to expect are kinda likely to be pushed away as it doesn't even compare in basic functions to most older RPGs back in the 90's in UI terms.  i want to enjoy and play shadowrun stuffs i really do, ever since i first tried it outs with shadowrun returns i kinda really liked the setting and stuffs.  it was different, and i enjoyed it, tired of medieval fantasy games... so many over the years, however being an MMO like RPG, i finds that coming into the game with no one else, as a new player~ is a nightmare~ when i thoughts it was gonna be a bit funs... having a blast doing random PUGs with strangers and stuffs... insteads i finds the UI to be nonexistant, press every key nothings for informations... nothings =( not even proper tooltips for certain things~ slang cheatsheet? an accurate community guide? an active wiki page?...

the chat is the worst~ it's not inviting to see as you first enter the game~ LFG spam galores! yay... doesn't this look funs... an LFG timesink from the 90's / early 2000's~ not one of these please... it's 2016~ seriously~ grouping functions is basic MMORPG 101~ no one wants to sit&LFG
still have yet to party with anyone... let alones chat with anyone =\ the chat is just lfg spam so why bother chatting with that mess going on

i just expected more functionality i guess by now, and the snappy attitudes ingame from the community well the one guy that does talk... isn't really motivating me to continue playing with that kinda playerbase =(

i wish the devs the best, and if the unity engine is really that bad, i'm sorry =\nnot sure if unity looked like a good choice back thens or what,
but i know there were other good reputable choices at the time...

i hope you guys can make the game more new player friendly~ it's not like i want daily respec or anythings, i don't even like min~maxing, i prefer a theme like character where i stick to a certain style no matter the penalty/bonus cuz i don't care, i'm not a greedy child that wants to maximize everthings cuz woO~big#... i just wants to has funs~
i wish the devs all successful lives, where~ever their decisions may lead~
