reviewText:
There are a LOT of problems with this game but I'm just going to list the big ones.

1. This game is inferior to shadowrun returns/dragonfall in almost every way. The writing is worse astheticly the game looks a lot worse with the use of lower quality 3d models as backgrounds as opposed to the digitally rendered art used in the aforementioned games and the game as a whole feels alot less polished than returns. The only way in which it improves upon its predicessors is with Co-op.

2. Lack of dialogue options. They have essentially removed the RP part of an rpg. In the 3 hours I played this game can you geuss how many different dialougue options ive seen? 2!! 2! hello" and "goodbye". The entire game is scripted with you playing a character whose personality has been determined entirely for you. The ability to change situations based on your characters chosen etiquette (something you cant even do in this game) has been a core mechanic of EVERY shadowrun game
date: both tabletop and videogame.\n\n3. BUGS BUGS BUGS BUGS BUGS....BUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUGSSSSSS. Models glitch out
recommended:
there is clipping everywhere the game is super unresponsive (this may or may not have something to do with the fact that it tries to check in with the server like every 10 seconds)

4. It tries to check in with the server like every 10 seconds??? Why? I dunno cause screw you its "Shadowrun Online". The current game is experiencing issues similar to Diablo 3 before they added an offline mode. Oh! did I mention that there is (as far as I can tell) NO OFFLINE MODE.

5. This game is heinously overpriced for what it is
hoursPlayed: I could maybe see recomending this for $ 10-15 once they fix some of the bugs.....maybe."

reviewText:
I have over one hundred hours clocked in on this game and I simply can't recommend it, as it's blatantly obvious it still is not a solid release candidate.

While the gameplay, when you are actually able to experience it, is quite enjoyable, it is marred by a lacking UI, character information and frequent bouts of server lag and other connectivity and game engine flaws that make the bulk of the experience utterly frustrating.

As of the time of this review, yet another problem has cropped up: the inability to even log into the game. For over 24 hours, hundreds of players have been unable to play any of their characters, or create new ones as the game's Friend and Chat server already has their accounts registered as online, and as with much of the development team's experience with online multiplayer has shown, a massive oversight has ensured there is absolutely no user-side method to log off such a connection.

Combine this with a woeful lack of support communicating with the players and you have yourself an experience tailored strictly for those with a deep passion for the source material, or those with wavering standards for quality in gaming.

reviewText:
Our dream come true: an MMO based on Shadowrun.

Only the world is not a true MMO, and the game is basically a linear shooter with some multiplayer capabilities.  MMOs have a wide range of activities you can follow.  They offer RP, crafting, exploration, public kudos, and best of all, when done right, a nonlinear story line that assure if you do not like a few adventures you are not stuck - you just work around them.  The city is a single dorky square with five vendors in it, whose weapons slowly get better as you do.  You never find better weapons on adventures, and while the clothing system is charming it is also limited.

The most disturbing thing is this idea that the entire charcter advancement system to endgame is nothing more than a normal MMO's noob area, and that at the end you will get to see the rest of the city in all of its glowing and really start playing,  Only there is no evidence that when you get 10 ranks in two or three areas that you will be released into a huge world, only that the MMO will have ended with a fizzle.

On the good side, the game is essentially a late alpha release with a Final Candidate price tag - a not uncommon experience.  That means it could grow.  Open the city up, expand the adventures, loose the linear designs, introduce housing and bars and mass transit, and the rest of the game experience and it could be a winner.

reviewText:
The game was off to a disastrous start with ALOT of lag problems but they seemed to be fixed for the most part.
But my big beef with the game is the following.
At the kickstart they promised an immersive game where you could more or less roam free and make choices that would make a difference in the world. They promissed a wide range of options/skills/magic etc)
They got alot of money via the kickstarter and via sales on steam and after a ridiculous amount of time (two years after Shadowrun Online which started at the same time) they managed to produce:
- a rigid gameplay that is even too simple for a SNES game and graphics to boot
- NO choices
- a ridiculously restrictive skill system

The ONLY redeeming features are: except for the solved lag, pretty bug free and 'it is shadowrun...barely'

I am so disappointed that I want to puke. For me this feels like a major 'take the money and run' operation.

Don't bother, the game requires constant connection to their servers which cannot be fixed and cause horendous lag after two hours of up time. This requires them to restart the servers without ingame notification.

reviewText:
Huge dissapointment:(

I'm an enormous fan of Shadowrun series and what made me fall in love with it is:
1, 2 and the 3 - the intricacy, subtlety and the level of suprise of the story. It's a first game in my gaming history experience that presented a challange in language sense (I mean how often do you use words like 'myopic', 'reneg' or 'eidetic') and I love it!  Every sentence was gem. As a result every character had character, their own idenity. Characters, places, moments..
4- Music - very indulging and allowing to really dive into the story.
5 - Graphics - beautiful...locations, places..everything
6 - Gameplay and interface - great, not perfect, but very good imho.

I was so excited to hear of a new episode, Chronicles, then I bought it instantly and that was a shoot in the foot. And here's why:
1. Graphics suck! Srsly, are we in 2002 again?? Not only the universe, but the interface as well...guys, did someone actually bother to QA the game? There are spelling errors and the font is just bleah...
2. Voice over is B+ average. I did miss voiceover in Shadowrun, but with this I'm happy to go back to no voice at all. And what's with the half voiced and half not? And this clicking after every sentence...
3. Character buildup - weird, it has no connection to the series at all. The perks are odd (why can you pick 'hacking' 3 times? What was wrong with using classinc numbering system?)
4. Gameplay is a pain - sure, I understand the strategy element, but since you can't really scroll away to far, it almoast feels like you're moving in turtle pace. How many moves do you have to do to get from one corner to the other.
5. Interface is confusing - my character died on my first mission and there was this odd icon that appeared stating most probalby that I have 5 turns before I..I don't know...like die completly but I had no idea what to do with it. I couldn't clik on a character, my NPCs where standing directly on her in a desprerate attempt to maybe save her like you would normaly with Trauma Kit in the old Shadowrun but nothing happened and I faid the mission.

General look and feel is just revolting. Sorry. From the moment my character woke up in that hospital I was like...whaaaa? what is that? Is this Shadowrun? Reeeeeally? Please, tell me it's not...

All in all, if you want to have it, at lease wait for a sale and get it for $4 as in my opinion it's not worth more, and definely not $20 I paid.

reviewText: It Is NOT the same as Return to Shadowrun. Very basic system. Combatsystem is closer to jagged alience than RTS. So beware if You think you will continue you adventures from RTS in better graphic's. They have very little commen ground.\nAlso importaint to know its aimed at multiplayer co-op. If you Tend to go solo you will have to struggle with a very lowbuged henchman system were you take 1-3 (i guess either playermade or random generated) henchmen with you for that mission. Theres no party and you cant manipulate the henchmen. They are equipped pre-teamup, and use to very poor equipped. You yourself have 2 itemslots, but only players can utilize that option, hence the npc-henchmen never have a granade or a medpack. Not even a pill to help them. The enemy does. Your party have to share the 2 things you choose to bring. Theres is also no revives, stabalizes or anything in that direction other that the medkit. Did I say your party have to share those 2 things. Your combat options are also very basic and constricted. You have a main and maybe a secondary, most npc's only the main which makes them very specilized to handle enemys. Some are immune to magic and hence the mage have to find other targets to engage as his or her attacks cant harm that enemy and they havent got any options to use melee or alternative weapon. So very arcade'ish. Hopes for the future depth of the combat system complexity isnt high.\nIf you want online player co-op turn base and dont mind the low complexity this might be fun. If you have standards regarding that you will be happier with the top-down RTS:dragon fall or other. Ufo-series (not x-com). X-com enemy unknows is good though!

reviewText:
Don't be fooled by the Shadowrun name!  This game is not created by the same company that brought us Shadowrun returns / Dragonfall / H.K.  That company is hairbrained schemes.  While the screen shots, and videos give this game the same feel, the gameplay and quality is completely different.  The controls are clunky, there are graphic glitches everywhere, and it is just not fun at all.

I feel bad for the team behind this game, because they truly love it, and put a lot of hard work into it, but clearly it was just not ready to be published yet.

TL:DR  This game is not by hairbrained schemes, controls are clunky, gameplay isn't very good, lots of glitchs.  PASS

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Second review - Still a waste...
I was asked to reconsider my negative review, but these updates didn't change much. I'll keep what I said before and add more:
1. Character creation and stories are still overly simple and dull. Come on... Shadowrun is a complex system and games based on it are supposed to make you think much more than this. Sheesh... Are you making a game for babies with all these ready made choices and these silly dialogues?
2. The interface is a mess that lacks lots of usability concepts, the music isn't synced to events, and the game is still performing horribly. As a software engineer myself I'm becoming curious as to what technology can be so bad to make such an unresponsive and clunky game... It's either what is being used or the competence of both designers and devs is not so good. Seriously... If I were a dev in this team I'd either vote for a complete reboot or quit my job because I wouldn't be able to stand our own product.
This game makes me want to tell this team to stop trying, which is a damn pity and makes me feel ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing bad too because I want to love every single thing based on Shadowrun but man... Getting back on this game to check the updates" has given me depressive thoughts and kind of ruined my night.

reviewText:
An X-Com:EU clone with a degree of focus on co-op multiplayer.

The devs stepped up and put massive amounts of polish into the game before launch, it's now slick and pretty playable.  The problem is that it's still very content-light; it lacks the features and depth you'd expect of competitors like Shadowrun Returns.

The progression system and gameplay diverges heavily from the Pen-and-Paper ruleset, and is pretty unremarkable.  The game has potential, but there is so little content that you can see pretty much everything on offer well before the end of the main story.

The lack of class / XP limits means it's only a matter of time until all characters have maxed out abilities in all fields - so there is pretty much no individuality between characters - and that's if you ignore how superficial the choices presented in the skill-trees are.

The Shadowrun setting is well realised and atmospheric as ever, but unfortunately the game just doesn't do enough with it to justify buying it at present.  That said, it's not un-fun"; it can be strangely addictive despite its flaws.  But there's better examples of both the game's genre

reviewText:
I tried to give this game a chance. I'm not anti-change, so while my previous Shadowrun experiences were with Shadowrun Dragonfall and Shadowrun Returns I was prepared to give the benefit of the doubt to this game's distincly different mechanics.

Unfortunately, the game is worse in literally every way than the Harebrained Schemes releases. It's so bad that I'm writing a review to complain about how bad it is.

If you like your RPGs to have a story and NPCs with actual background stories, I would skip this game. To make matters worse, there's no control over the difficulty setting and limited opportunities for in-game healing. As such, the game is unreasonably difficult to play successfully even in the early runs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At this point of development, I can't recommend this game (as much as I like Shadowrun). When you can't even finish the final mission in the tutorial, there is something wrong. I've attempted this mission about 20 times now. Always the same outcome. The player characters miss most of the time. The NPC's rarely ever miss. In some cases, the NPC's with the swords can take down the player characters in two hits. Seems to be balanced toward the game defeating the player. This is bad design as if you can't progress, what's the point in playing. There are plenty of other games out there.

Maybe the dev's will bring some better balance to the game when it hits it's final release, but if not, this was a waste of money.

reviewText:
In the current state this is one of the most awful games I've played in years. So laggy it takes MINUTES between triggering an action and the action taking place. Constantly locking up during loading screens. Patches with no patch notes. Downtimes with no warning or posts about it on any medium. Constant nerfs.

No way to respec your skills even after they ruin skills you picked despite the promise of refunding points if they make skill changes.

shops having items for sale at the correct mission progress but once you can afford them they're not on the shop anymore.

Only viable way to play is be a cybered up elf with automatic weapons because cyberware gives you crazy bonuses that non-cyber characters can't even compete with. Hell the highest auto in the game is vastly superior to any other weapon even before you add cyberware.

No information at all, be it in game like what exactly this skill does, or any info from devs about what changed this patch, when they're going to take down the server.

No ignore function to block the toxic should be playing league of legends" players. No whisper so you can talk to people without trying to get your message seen in global chat through all the complaining about lag.

No LFG function so you just have to spam the already spammy global chat. henchmen allow you to run a NPC person on the team but they're so bloody weak compared to players with their bad skill choices and lack of secondary weapon that you're stuck LFG until you find 3 people or just get tired of waiting and quit.

Developers are so busy posting video's of themselves PLAYING shadowrun when they should be FIXING shadowrun.

Most of the rules we know from the books are thrown out so forget the paper rule books as none of it applies and you'll end up having to remake your characters if you base decisions that way since there's no real data to go off of. (manastorm: DEVISTATES enemies in a large area... 16 dmg is devistates? when everyone has 30-50hp by then??? and it takes ALL your mana???)

Decking is called Hacking but tehre's also a "loot skill" called hacking so it gets confusing when talking to potential team members (can you hack? yeah I'm a hacker. *invite

reviewText:
Shadowrun Online - Now Chronicles Boston Lockdown is literly an abortion.

After Cliffhanger in Vienna realized there was no way possible they were capable of fullfilling promises to fans and kickstarter backers they changed the name to Chronicles.  They scrubbed all original documentaion of development plans and goals from Shadowrun.com.  The reason is that they are trying to blame the fans and backers for thinking the game was going to be an mmorpg...which was the original plan!

Cliffhanger productions is the most unethical company i have seen.  All of their positive reviews on steam are from friends,  family and people they give free access codes to.  Once a month they have open houses and give away free access codes,  then asked people to review the game.  90% of the positive reviews on steam are free access users.  This is how they falsely manipulate user reviews. They try despertly to keep the steam rating mixed which should be, without manipulation, overwhelmingly negative.

I don't have allot of time explaining how horrible this game is,  just read the negative reviews to get an honest review.

If you originally backed this project on kickstarter...contact kickstarter and inform them of this Cliffhangers lies and practices. With enough negative feedback kickstarter won't let this company have another fraudulent campaign to rip off fans and then blame the fans for their mistakes.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAfter trying the latest version I have to admit that the game has improved consistently I used to be a gamemaster for the pen and paper version of the game during the 2nd and 3rd edition era and I have familarized myself with the fourth ed. I was cyked to see a Shadowrun game with a multiplayer mode but was very disappointed with the early version of the game. I like where the new version is heading but is still missing a lot of the quirks that made the Shadowrun universe such a great background to develop into a video game. For instance, I understand that the devs don't want it to be a clone of Shadowrun Return but that game used the fourth edition as a template and made sense to a table player. I applaud the new improvements and will be on the look out for other changes, I wish for the addition of the adept class and powers and more look custumization options... I will recommend this game when it'll meet my standards and taste as a Shadowrun hardcore fan...

reviewText:
Dear Developers / Community!

Before I started playing Shadowrun Chronicles, I have read a lot of mixed reviews on it, what were more negative than positive. Now that I have played the game for a couple of days, I would like to share my findings with you.

The overall feel of the game 5/5
It delivers the feeling of the Shadowrun universe perfectly. Some players are not happy with the character customization, some want more content, or more MMO utility out of it, but I think we can all agree that when you jump into the mission together with your fellow runners, the shooting starts and a hive controller is wailing at you, now thats how Shadowrun should feel like. I give a solid 5 out of 5 here.

Character customization 3/5
This is always a cricital point of every game with RPG elements. The hardcore wants to have all the options, the softcore wants to jump into the play with choosing a pre-planned levelling path. Compared to Shadowrun Returns / Dragonfall (they would get 5/5), this game has simplified build mechanics, but that doesnt mean you cant make choices, or cant screw it up! I give a score of 3 because this simpler character building is more appealing to the masses, and compared to a single player game, we do want some company here.

How the multiplayer feels 5/5
This is a turn based strategy game, what is bound to be sluggish at least, because players are weighing options, choosing skills, thinking about the best tactics - every single time they make a turn. This was my biggest fear when I was thinking how the multiplayer will fare in Shadowrun Chronicles. But, and kudos to the devs here, its not sluggish, you dont feel like waiting for anybody unless they really take their time of course. Your actions and the turns flow in a comfortable pace, and apart from the occasional lagspike, it never felt slower than single player to me. A solid 5 out of 5 for the implementation.

Content 2/5
The quests are great, not too much detail to bore the action boys, but still enough to make you feel part of the world, and with voice acting too what really helps the atmosphere. There are just not too many of them (yet, the devs claim), and after you conquer all, not much is left to do apart from replaying them. You can probably finish off the entire main questline in a week, and that is first time playing it, and taking it slow. If you only have one or two hours to play in the evenings it will last you longer, but in summer break a dedicated runner can beat the whole thing in 5 days.

They either have to heat up those end game challenges / give us more main quests, or work on the replayability. All of these are promised by the devs already, who are a lovely bunch by the way, their communication is outstanding. I give 2 out of 5 here because if you have a real life and can only play in the evenings, the main questline will entertain you for weeks, and thats not too bad.

Is this an MMO at all? 2/5
If you expected the traditional MMO experience, you will be disappointed. This game is more like a single player game where you can play with your buddies.

There is no support function for organizing groups, no guilds (although there is a friends list function), and the chat system is so basic that you cant even whisper to another player. You have global chat where the runs are organized, and party chat when you are in a mission with your fellow runners. No shared bank to exchange items between your characters, and absolutely no way to trade between players.         <- If a developer reads this, you can take all of these as my suggestions to improve the game.

The balance between running with players and hiring henchmen is perfect though, so I give it 2 out of 5. You are never forced to group with anyone, you can go single player all the way, still if you group, its more fun. This kind of flexibility is a must in todays gaming. Players want to have a choice, and not to be forced into grouping with random strangers.

All in all, thank you developers for making a game I enjoy this much, and I ll see you online chummers.

Tenet

reviewText:
At least once a week I've been grouping with chummers from my clan to play through this game.
Having an absolute blast. Playing for 4-5 hours at a time, per session. It's become our Friday night ritual.
The co-op is very good.
The random damage meter is very unforgiving.
The character creation is good.
Storyline is so-so.
The missions are very tactful, well designed and requires some team work if playing a group.
I'm having a great time with this.

reviewText: I am only a mission in and try out different characters, but a few things are VERY apparent. If your on a mac, you have to run the game, force quit and then reopen to be able to play. If you have to go afk for anything over 5-10min, you get a server boot. Server boots wouldn't be so bad except it also closes the game and i get to start the double open all over again. Barring that pain in the butt, like the game so far and will continue to play in the hopes that these bugs/server issues can be resolved.

reviewText:
Lag is horrendous. Lacks depth of choices, hopefully coming in updates (spells, spirits,wpns, equip, et all). Even with the latter the game does well at char. creation and visually sets the proper tone. It has promise. The online ability to run with other players is a unique touch. I can see where tehy wanted to go with this, but they just didn't end up there. Once, the lag or latency issues are cleared up and maybe some better voice acting, it will be a close to contending to HareBrained Schemes SW offering which is a bit more faithful to the old SEGA version.

**May 8th**
In a most personal touch, the team has pulled through. Thanks for contacting me Primetide. I respect that greatly! I can now recant the previous review. Lag has been fixed and anything else mentioned above is simple fluff to add. I continued to play through the lag and server resets, made Green Monster a heck of a level to complete. >;/
Now for someone wanting that old school feel but with the option of running with real, live meat-bags or those drekkin point-ears. This is your game!  Great PR and getting on top of the situation, you guys    recovered with class. If you see Tharn in game, bug him to buy you a soy-kaf chummer. :)

reviewText: UPDATE: Not long after I wrote my initial review, a final series of reboots and patches seems to have completely fixed the lag I was originally so fired up about, and the game is now quite playable. There are still some growing pains, this is not a finished product by a long shot, it's more like an extended public beta, but it's now to a point where I would actually recommend people give it a try.\n\nORIGINAL REVIEW: Despite what they've said about fixing server lag issues, the lag is still horrible weeks after launch. I don't think I got my Kickstarter's worth out of this, and at this rate, not sure I want to wait around until it's playable. Recommending anyone interested in Shadowrun instead look at the single-player games (Shadowrun Returns, SR: Dragonfall, and the upcoming SR: Hong Kong).

reviewText:
Shadowrun Chronicles is a tactical coop game based on the Shadowrun universe which isn't quite finished yet. But on a very good way.

Shadowun Flavor:
Yes, this is NOT the Shadowrun from Harebrained Schemes, it's not even like it. This Shadowrun is a different approach, a new interpretation. If you just can stand original works, this is not your game.

Developement:
This game had its bad days, where it was nearly unplayable. This is quite the past and the devs are making great progress. There is nearly allways some of them in the forums and they do care about the opinions of the players. You can see that they are commited to their product and the players.

Content:
There is enough content to keep you entertained for some hours. If you want, you can play through it in one or two days. After that it gets a litte bit repeating with running the story. But repeatable missions are in the making and should be soon released.

Community:
Great guys, not many (yet), but mature.

Conclusion:
If you like Shadowrun and like tactical games, you want to give this a try.
If you are looking for an exact multiplayer copy of Shadowrun Returns, Dragonfall or Hongkong, you will be disappointed.

reviewText: This game emulates a recently revived beloved game, but not Shadowrun: Returns. This game feels like XCOM: Enemy Unkown set in the Shadowrun universe except instead of a focus on building your base and squad, it's all about building up your one character. Every mission is heavily combat-focused, there's no dialogue options or speech-skills. Instead the greater focus on combat means missions are built with this in mind with lots of fighting however they're usually quick affairs with longer runs being broken up into several encounters. The game is co-op focused however if you're running solo fear not! The game has a very interesting henchmen system whereby if you are going solo or below the game's (generally) 4-player size requirement, you can place into your team characters made by other players under your control, meaning you can cruise through this game solo if you want.\nTL:DR - If you want a Shadowrun RPG with a bit more of an XCOM flavour, you've found it. Very good game, 7/10.

reviewText:
Having played Harebrained Studios' excellent Shadowrun Returns and Dragonfall RPGs I came to Chronicles with information like this is an online-only co-op focused game made by another studio and which initially had some pretty terrible reviews that have since improved with the regular patches. Being a single player person I was wondering whether this game would do it for me but after giving it a chance I have to say it is a good game.

While Boston Lockdown may not have the full-fledged RPG mechanics of SR and SR:D (favouring a somewhat simpler skill tree) it is a Shadowrun experience with turn-based tactical combat, good 3D - if simple - graphics and - more importantly to me - you can solo the story campaign without problems if you build your character carefully. The story is interesting and there is character building across the campaign. One thing to bear in mind is that multiple aspects of the rich Shadowrun world (which is a long running pen and paper RPG first) are not fully introduced so it would be better if you play another Shadowrun game first to familiarise yourself with the setting so as to fully enjoy it.

Of course this being an online co-op-focused game, the game's hub is one relatively small map that acts as a stop-over shopping and discussion location where you will see other players walking around but you can solo the whole thing without problems. As the main story progresses the hub changes to reflect current events and you do get side missions regularly after the introductory missions are over. The only thing preventing this being a serviceable offline SR game is the always online requirement (saves are server side) and the small easy to ignore chat window on the bottom left. As the developers do not have the rights to make an offline game this is an understandable compromise but I do hope it gets a full offline mode sometime in the future so the game lives on past the servers. The difficulty especially in the beginning is quite high which makes for an interesting challenge and pushes you to plan and execute carefully.

So TL;DR: Yes, this is a good Shadowrun game for single player types and scratches that turn based Shadowrun itch in between the Harebrained studios core entries.
